reviewText: I loved the concept of an underwater survival/crafting/sandbox adventure, and this game did a little more than merely scratch the surface of that; but is FAR capable of doing so much more.  The art design, the music, the crafting system all work to create a tranquil gaming experience.  The storyline is basic - survive, repair and return - you decide how/when/where to do that.  There are a variety of aquatic life forms - both flora and fauna - to delight the eye and add to immersion; but insufficient to encourage re-playability without the player's own ingenuity.   The cooking/farming and crafting are entertaining, but expanding those skills falls short of really essential.  That all being said - its a game I return to time and time again, and still thoroughly enjoy!\n\nThere are mysteries to unravel - decisions to be made, and not just the ones mandated by the story mode.  Nuances of the environment(s) to explore.  The game is more than just find the pieces"
date: but we (the player) have to make it so; being able to mod it would go a LONG way toward extending re-playability. As a single person team
recommended: it would also go a long way toward removing the governors from this project allowing this game to truly do the genre justice!   There is SUCH awesome potential laying fallow here for a phenomenal game!\n\nWould I recommend it?  Yes

reviewText:
I enjoy watching marine wildlife loom steadily into view and eventually off into the murk.
As a straight survival game, FarSky has a good balance between challenge and playability.  I like to explore and I like combat, and I had fun playing it.  I usually only build what is useful and necessary in sandbox games, so the simplicity of the bases and equipment was not a negative for me.
I most enjoyed Survival mode, available upon completion of the initial Adventure mode.  The increased difficulty of Survival mode made the game quite challenging and required careful resource management decisions.  It was most satisfying to earn my way back up to the top of the food chain.
Survival Advice:  At your first opportunity, make two underwater scooters to alternate between.  Move extractors around.  One can always open the inventory screen and heal at leisure, so carry ample food and bandages.  Predators only attack when there is blood in the water (or at night), so hunt with caution or while carrying serious firepower.  Enough harpoon cannons around your base can tranform threats into food.  There is no easier target to hit than one heading directly at you.

reviewText:
I'm giving a reluctant thumbs up. The reason is the unique setting: surving and building a camp under water? Yes, please! :D

The first couple of hours are both the most interesting and the most frustrating. There's no handholding in this game. Figuring out how to build, repair, keep your hunger in check and gather resources are all up to you. Frustrating, but not EXACTLY in a bad way. After finally figuring out I had to first craft a knife so I could hunt fish, I felt like a bad ♥♥♥ not dying of hunger, and even more after finding out how that cooker worked to lower the hunger percentage even MORE. So more tutorials certainly could improve this game, but it didn't hinder me that much.

What did hinder me, though, was that after the initial surface of the game, there were no advanced techniques. Once you've learned how to basically survive, explore, expand and repair your base, you're pretty much done. And that's a pity. There is a huge amount of potential for much more than what actually is in this game. Since this is a one man's job, I can't really expect AAA-like polish and finesse, but even then...it has more going for it than there currently is (droid control, sleeping mechanics, food preservation, advanced base customization, ...).

However, I need to stress that while not playing as a critic, I certainly had fun. It's nice to explore, see what you can find and scavenge the bottom of the sea in search of resources. It has great immersion and the setting is (as I said in the beginning of this review) unique. Kind of sad the developer stopped adding things, but I wouldn't say it's an unfinished product.

reviewText:
FarSky,

I do very much love this game, I am quick to rage about most things in almost any game, but this game I couldn't find any flaw other than the simple fact that there isn't too much content, and it's very very short / easy after you have a good amount of hours on it ex 5-6 hours.

The graphics for this game may seem a bit childish, but that's what's so relaxing about it. It is not a super-serious game, but it gives you the under-water aquatic life style feel you want.

The music for the game is lovely, I'd buy the soundtrack if I had money to spare for it.

The idea of the campaign is to find 9 pieces of your missing submarine, while expanding your aquatic underwater base to survive and gather equipment.

Hunt fish for food, but be wary as sharks and other predators will smell the blood and attack you.

There are 3 levels of depth in the game, which you can easily clear if you mine the ores and create the necessary equipment.  Which becomes very redundant in the sandbox mode which at most can entertain you for a good 16 hours.

I do reccomend this game as I bought it on sale for $4.99, but I would not reccomend paying the full price of the game as others have mentioned it is not worth the $15 full price.

reviewText:
Thumbs up on the condition that you buy it on sale. $15 is too much but at even $10 I would call it worth it for a fast game that you'll play through twice and then drop it. If you know what you're going to get going in, it's fun.

This is a super bare-bones survival crafting game. The number of objects you can craft is in the area of 30, no mod support, and the Dev has declared the game complete. So don't expect Minecraft.

For all that it fun to tool around the ocean for a few hours. Explore the depths, get murdered by sharks and worse. The game does a good job at atmosphere, so soak it up.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This is a very short, but very well made game. The developer has said that it was intentionally made short so that is to be expected. The visuals are great and the atmosphere is amazing.

The crafting system is not the most intuitive, but definitely not bad by any means. It has a little bit of story to it, but it still feels very immersive. No voice acting lends to this game's pros.

The hardest aspect of the game is figuring out where to find materials since the game doesn't actually say, but one quick google search cleared it all up for me. The sea creatures were very well modeled and textured, and the map, while small, was enjoyable yet tense (in a good kinda way) to explore.

Overall, I love this game and highly recommend it, but I personally don't know if 20 dollars is the best price for it. It has no multiplayer, no mods, and no more updates coming so I would probably wait until it goes on sale before buying it if you're on the fence with the price. Otherwise, it's a great experience.

reviewText:
I merely stumbled upon this while watching several YouTubers play this game (ie LordMinion777, BestInSlot, etc.), and honestly, I was expecting to buy another laggy game by accident. You know, the kind where you are lagging to the point of insanity; unable to play your purchase?! However, when I went to launch it, Javascript came up. That was when I knew: this was going to be a great lag-free experience! Everyone who owns a Mac: This will not disappoint. Of course, you may want to watch gameplay of it first, to get familiar. But otherwise, this is a flowing game! The dynamics of it are great, and the crafting is very simplistic: making gameplay fun to any new players! I highly recommend it. There are in fact three modes of play, one of which mut be unlocked by beating the game once. The Adventurer is for all easy play; with little predator NPCs and such, and easy spawns. The Survivor gamemode installs fears like you wouldn't believe. Sharks and other predators spawn more frequently, and have a higher count, making exploration a nightmare. Finally, there is the sandbox mode, where you take any gold you've found in any of the other two gamemodes and decide what items you spawn with, the map seed, and so on.

Overall, I would recommend it to those who want an easy, laid back, material-mining gaming experience, with the beauty of the ocean's depths!

(Only con here to report is the bug where sound in the game sorta stops, unless you quit and re-enter the game. Idk if thats happened to anyone else, but it is for me!)

On the plus side, it features amazing landscapes on the bottom of the ocean, ranging from a colorful reef to the almost dark abyss of the deep sea.

reviewText:
To put this game shortley. and I may be wrong on this I only played the story mode where you have to resurface.

I want to talk about map layout first. The depths seem to be divided in three sections. highest has sharks, barracudas (if i spelled that correctly.)  generic fish life, and iron.  Mid depth has copper, more fish types, frill sharks, and angler fishes. bottom level has giant octopi,

You have to play the story to unlock survival, i believe. But the story is short. collect 9 submarine peices and resurface.  to get the sub peices you have to make a suit able to handle the next level of depth.

mechanics in the game. you have a limited air supply which you have to return to base to refill. there are a few vegetables you can farm in your base as well as hunting fish. (blood will spill and attract predators. from what i recal and you can get a bleeding status in this game.) you have 5 jumps to so you feel good about climbing back up the cliff face.

My issue with the game.. I haven't played the survival so i don't know if there is more to it or not... in story from what i saw, even after getting the sub you could only dive 350 meters down. when you depth gauge would list hundreds more.. and you can stare off into the abyss... so further exploration is just sitting there teasing you. not letting you have it... you get used to the predators FAST. They also kinda loose their threat when you get a spear gun.. which is the only real weapon you can use against them.. the knife is more for hunting and the predators... well arn't easy to just hunt.  I guess where I'm going with this is.. I got used to it to fast. As while it has a lot to offer. it doesn't stay new as long as i wish it would.

I love the idea of a game like this.. I just wish there was more to it than there is.. that's not nessicarilly a bad thing.. it left me wanting more.. and i can only hope there will be more added. But for now.. is it worth the 15$.. the fact that i realized 3 hours had passed only after they had passed.  is a good notion to it being worth it.. but how long before it becomes repetative to me is what makes me wonder if the 15$ is worth it.

reviewText:
Outstanding game! I am playing it on Linux Mint XFCE, and it plays great! Thank you to the publisher for making this game available on Linux and actually making sure that it works before you sold it to people.

This is not a hardcore game, but it is a very fun way to spend some time away from reallity.

Collecting gold to spend in the sandbox mode is a little strange though. But overall this is a very solid, well built game, and worth every penny.

P.S. If you are having trouble with full screen in Ubuntu, just go to options and toggle it off even if it says that it already is, then go back in and toggle it back on, and it should be in full screen mode now (A very minor glitch I ran into when I had Ubuntu installed on my laptop).

reviewText: Game is good for a couple of hours of ♥♥♥♥♥ and gigs. It's a nice looking environement, with a solid sound track to boot. Game plays pretty smoothly and the oxygen mechanic will keep you on your toes, making sure that you make the most of every second you spend out of base, gathering those precious resources. Combat's what you'd expect, nothing overly spectacular. You can pretty much kill anything with the same technique. My only quarrel is that it didn't really have much to offer after you'd maxed your gear, crafted all the shiny stuff, and completed the adventure mode, which can be done quite easily in about 4-5 hours. Overall if you're looking for something that's short and sweet, fairly immersive and not overly fast paced than this game is going to be the way to go. If you're looking for something with a bit more to keep you entertained in the long run, then at the moment this probably wouldn't be the best option. Overall a good game, with a beautiful environment, enjoyable to play, though just a little limited.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
FarSky is one of the most paradoxically tense and soothing games I've played in recent years.

On the one hand, the deep sea theme is beautiful and calming. The graphics are a bit chunky and aren't anything to write home about, but they get the point across without feeling cluttered and there are lots of pretty sea creatures and seascapes to look at.

At the same time, the constant pressure of the depleting air tank, Nathan the Diving Man's stomach, and all of the pretty sea creature who want to murder the heck out of you keep the game from being a walk in the park.

This is not a long game, nor is it a particularly difficult one. Taking even basic precautions should keep you from getting eaten and skilled survivor gamers will probably be able to beat both Adventure AND the more difficult Survivor mode in just a few hours. That said, if you have the money so spare and a few hours to kill, the game it definitely worth it.

reviewText:
Now that the big bugs seem to have been ironed out (on my end) for now, here's another review!

I rather enjoy the atmosphere of the game. I'm a sucker for underwater environments, and this one is a rather pretty, stylized one. Resource-gathering is also relatively easy compared to other survival games; resources are quite easy to spot, and you can put Extractors on resource deposits to mine while you explore.

This may mean, however, that the game is a bit too easy for Survival fans. The story mode is short, crafting is rather simplistic and there are far too few recipes. The sandbox suffers because of the lack of crafting; sure, you can make a huge underwater base, but you'll quickly run out of stuff to put in the rooms, for decoration or otherwise. Even the nastier creatures near the end of the game become pushovers once you've gotten some end-game items, which, again, aren't particularly hard to get thanks to Extractors.

I hope the game's sparseness means that there will be content updates and such. Otherwise, the price tag is a little harder to justify. Still, I recommend it if only for the atmosphere, and I hope the devs expand this lovely game!

reviewText:
It was totally worth the $15 dollar price, I was hooked in from the very moment I started a new randomly generated world. The core gameplay is based around gathering minerals and finding food. All the while fighting off all manner of sea creatures, whether it be barracuda, sharks of various species or giant squid (or octopi).

This game will want you to keep playing for hours on end, its refreshing to see an adventure survival game that isnt FULLY voxel based, the base building is of course voxel based for simplicity, but this still allows for some intricate and beautiful designs.

While its not exactly a system pusher or the next crysis, the art style is consistent(all be it pixelated) in convincing you that you are under the ocean. And finally if you have a friend with a terrible pc that cant run much this game is extremely lightweight and stable as well.

7/10: because while it is lacking in alot of areas, what you get for 15 dollars really ammounts to 30+ hours of gameplay with multiple missions immersing you in the deep blue along with a relaxing casual play style compelling you to take it slow.

reviewText:
This game combines one of my biggest loves (Marine Life) with three of my biggest fears.  Shark Attacks, Dark Waters, and The concept of nothingness.  Playing the adventure mode of this game, the hair was standing on the back of my neck as I walked through forests of Kelp.  The telltale sign of a predator charging me and I almost screamed, not knowing from where in the fields it was coming from.

Then, I beat Adventure mode, and got to Survival.  More Predators, and less leniancy on death.

I was hunting for food, which caused blood.  Blood attracts predators.  Predators want to eat your face.  I was attacked by a shark, knocked into a ravine, and died from pressure.


That being said, this game is a lot of fun, and really beautiful.  The Crafting System is pretty simple, and really straightforward, there's the ability to customize your base, and there's a sense of urgency when travelling due to your oxygen limits.

I would definitely recommend giving this game a shot.  A low price for a good game.

You can find destroyed bases in which you can repair, and use to your ability, or destroy, and get resources. But sadly, it falls a bit when you realize, there are so many useless materials. And story mode is WAY to short. Sandbox mode is fun, but can also get repetitive. But this game is a lot of fun, but I'd recommend waiting for a sale, just incase you have crashing problems and can't fix them.

reviewText:
TL;DR: 4/10


This game is fun for about 12 hours, and then all of it's appeal practically dissappears. FarSky is a survival game, where you not only have to worry about hunger and drowning, but also the many predators of the ocean. The game takes place on 3 main levels. A level at around 80 meters below, consisting of mostly Iron Ore and Sharks. A level at around 200 meters, consisting of mostly Copper, Angler Fish, and Jellyfish. And finally a level at around 300 meters, consisting of krakens and manganese (Yeah, I can't pronounce it half the time, either.) In about 20 minutes you can go from broke on the first layer, to decked out in full Manganese gear, as it's not really hard to obtain anything. The main goal of the main game is to find the pieces of your submarine, and get back to the surface, but there's not much appeal to that. All of the fun is because it's underwater, so why would I want to go back to the surface? Honestly, if you just wanted to beat the game, you could just get the Manganese stuff and a propellor, and be done within an hour. If you're like me, however, you won't want to be done by the time you get the submarine. I personally found it more compelling to use the submarine to explore more of the reef and expand on my little hideaway than to just leave behind everything I'd worked on for the past 2 hours.

This game is fun if you want to spend a few hours going from having nothing, to just too much of everything. If you like replayability, I suppose it has the appeal of having a different world each time, but that really doesn't mean much other than that there might be more silver (the most rare material) in one world than another. The controls aren't the best, and the construction" is pretty bad. The music was good for a while

reviewText: The comparison with Minecraft is bound to be drawn, but honestly I find this more akin to farming-based games like Farming Simulator, Harvest Moon and Rune Factory. The crafting system is simple and utilitarian, it's not voxel-based, and there's no terraforming - resources are 'node' based, and you exhaust them with your hand-drill or with automated gathering devices you can find or make. The game is very focused on the procedures of sustaining oneself and surviving - producing food, collecting resources from the automatic gatherers etc. This lends itself well to a relaxing, project-based" style of play: make the gear you need to descend that ravine to the crystal node

reviewText:
Do Not Waste Your Time On This!
Farsky had great potential, when it was still being worked on.  After promisies of multiplayer and other things, it seemed great.  Then the developers gave up.  Now there are no more updates, and it never really left the alpha stage.

There are really no pros, aside from the fact that you can make underwater bases and fight sharks.  One of the really bad things is that whenever you switch windows, alt-tab or even just minimizing it, you lose everything unless you saved.

If you want a good game that involves underwater exploration, go check out Subnautica.

reviewText:
MINECRAFT BUT UNDERWATER!??!

Basically the game functions like minecraft but with much MUCH better graphics.

You need to collect resources, iron, magnese, copper?
What about some food, grow potatoes, carrots? or hunt for fish, maybe some jellyfish meat?

Maybe now your sick of eating raw fish and want to ear and stabalise yourself properly.
Well you do start with a very basic base in campaign or sandbox. This is definatly needed to start, those that say it ruins the sense of survival are SO wrong, your oxygen levels from your tank wont last long (at the start) so you need the base to re-air(?) etc, its VERY helpful for a pre-base to be made, anyway you can just move and start from scratch later.

You need to find new resources for new better items, you need to be brave and go deeper into the ocean to find the rarer items.

Risk your life, risk your oxygen, go deep, defend yourself from sharks, whales, jellyfish or whatever you find. Scavenge for food, eat and try to survive. CAREFUL dont go too deep at the start or you wont have enough stamina to jump/swim back up to a safe pressure level, your mask might start to crack - 8 seconds till your dead.

If you manage to get far enough, perhaps you will have multiple bases scattered in different areas with auto resources extractors, maybe you'll even have your own mini submarine for safe traveling?

Either way, build on an endless world, new areas. Objectives? - They are what you think them to be, its in the imagination.

I dont bother doing pros, only cons:

Cons:
- Lack of depth in advance-ability
- Lack of items
- Repetative danger - HOWEVER the quantity is different, maybe you will get attacked by one shark, next time its 5 ect.
- Get this resource to craft better gear = advance deeper in the ocean = level system (sort of)

Basically

For its current price

BUY IT!


- even at normal price, its still a great game. I spent 2 hours+ straight since i just couldnt close the game, just one more resource"

TRY IT!
"
